poem:
In the Grid of the Observer's Gaze

Sudoku, numbers unfurled,
a grid to fill, a world
riddled with one to nine -
each row, each line, divine. 

A secret rhythm in codes,
in every square it bodes,
unseen patterns twine,
an architecture of mind. 

Next week, the reveal: precise,
buy it not for its price,
but for the joy of chase
in the Observer's structured space.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Observer sudoku Click here to access the print version. Fill the grid using the numbers 1 to 9. Each number must appear just once in every row, column and 3x3 box. Buy next week’s Observer Digital Edition to see the completed puzzle.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Observer sudoku Click here to access the print version. Fill the grid using the numbers 1 to 9. Each number must appear just once in every row, column and 3x3 box. Buy next week’s Observer Digital Edition to see the completed puzzle.
